questions.text: A 35 year old male working with a hammer and chisel had an accident and a foreign body enters the eye. Which of these investigations will be detrimental?
questions.solution:
MRI is contraindicated in patients with a metallic origin body as they may get dislodged on applying external magnetic field and may cause further damage to the tissues.

IOC in this case - CT scan.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGl's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology pg 617

questions.text: Identify the investigation?
questions.solution:
Hysterosalpingography is performed during the first 6-10 days of menstrual cycle and is best performed during the second to fifth day interval just after the cessation of menstruation. The investigation being done here is Hysterosalpingography. It is used in infertility to check for the cause of infertility. Hysterosalpingography is the standard of care to look for tubal occlusion in all patients, unless laparoscopy is planned. Diagnostic laparoscopy and chromotubation are performed in women with suspicion of endometriosis or pelvic adhesions as HSG is not useful for detecting peritubal adhesions or endometriosis.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 347

questions.text: A 30 year old male complains of gradual swelling around the wrist for 3 months, Xray is given below. What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
GCT/osteoclastoma

Lesion is seen in epiphysis extending into the metaphysis. It is subarticular in nature.seen in mature skeleton ( growth plate fused).

Soap bubble lytic lesion.

Treatment - Extended curettage with bone grafting.

Mc site - Lower end of femur in epiphyses.

It is the most common bone tumor in the disend end of radius.

Chondroblastoma-

Epiphyseal lesion seen in mature skeleton . in age group < 20 years.

Most common site is the Upper end of the humerus.

KEY TAKEAWAY-


Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no l435

questions.text: A 30 year old female presenting with sterile pyuria. Radiograph is shown to identify the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Putty kidney refers to the extensive parenchymal and pelvicalyceal system calcification occurring in the kidney. This is usually seen in chronic tubercular infection when there is extensive parenchymal and pelvicalyceal system calcification in the kidneys resulting in atrophic scarred calcified kidneys.


Psoas Abscess.


Staghorn Calculus.


Nephrocalcinosis - it is of two types

  1. Medullary Nephrocalcinosis- seen in hyperparathyroidism, hypervitaminosis vitD, Medullary sponge kidney
  2. Cortical Nephrocalcinosis- seen in Alport syndrome, Cortical necrosis.

Key TAKEAWAY-


Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 97

questions.text: A child presents with cyanosis. Xray of the patient is given below identify the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
TAPVC can be divided into four main groups according to the site or sites of connection, supracardiac, cardiac, infracardiac and mixed. The chest radiographic picture depends on the type of TAPVC.

In supracardiac type, which is also the most common, the heart is enlarged, the pedicle is wide with a classical "figure of 8 or Snowman's" appearance, produced by the dilated left vertical and left innominate veins and the right SVC. The left atrium is small and there is increased flow, as evidenced by pulmonary plethora.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2637

questions.text: A 26 year old male with back ache, morning stiffness and reddening of eyes. X-ray of the patient is given below, Identify the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given xray shows bamboo spine due to osteophyte formation which is suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic, progressive inflammatory arthritis which chiefly involves the synovial joints of the spine along with the adjacent soft tissues as well as the sacroiliac joints, although peripheral, large joints such as the hips, shoulders and knee can also be involved.

Radiological features:

SI joints: The classic sacroiliitis is bilateral and symmetrical. Changes occur in both the synovial along with ligamentous (superior and posterior) parts of the sacroiliac joints.
The earliest radiographic findings occur in the subchondral cortex which appears blurred or lost.
Later, small (rat-bite) erosions appear which are worse along the iliac aspect of the joint. These cause widening of the joint space with hazy margins. This is followed by larger erosions, subjacent sclerosis and joint space narrowing as irregular new bone bridges the joint space with eventual ankylosis and resolution of the sclerosis.
The modified New York criteria is used for grading of sacroiliitis and was established in 1994.

Spine: Spinal involvement classically starts at the dorsolumbar or lumbosacral junction .
Erosions initially occur at the vertebral margins at the site of attachment of the outer fibers of the annulus fibrosus (Romanus lesions) with adjacent sclerosis (shiny corner sign).
Healing of these erosions or laying down of bone beneath the anterior longitudinal ligament causes "squaring" of the vertebral bodies, best appreciated on lateral radiographs of the lumbar spine.
Exuberant new bone formation may even cause anterior convexity of the vertebral body (barrel-shaped vertebrae).
ossifications may be seen in the interspinous ligaments and facet joints causing the dagger and tram-track signs respectively.
Facet joint ankylosis is the major factor causing loss of spinal mobility.


Dagger sign


Tram Track/Trolley sign

KEY TAKEAWAY- Radiological findings in Ankylosing Spondylitis.

Calcification of anterior longitudinal ligament.

Calcification of intervertebral disc giving rise to bamboo spine//Tram track sign/Trolley sign.

Calcification of interspinous ligament- dagger sign

On MRI -lesions seen in the anterior part of intervertebral disc [Andersson lesion ].

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI'S Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2830

questions.text: A patient presenting with abdominal pain and distension. Multiple air fluid levels are seen. Dilated loops are?
questions.solution:
Difference between jejunum and ileum
differences between the two:

  1. jejunum is slightly wider (< 3 cm) than ileum(<2 cm)
  2. jejunum folds (valvulae conniventes) are thicker (2-3 mm) than ileum folds (1-2 mm)
  3. jejunum folds are also more numerous and deeper than ileum folds
  4. ileal mesentery contains more fat than jejunal mesentery
  5. ileum tends to be smaller caliber than jejunum
  6. ileum tends to be lighter in color than the jejunum
  7. ileum contains abundant Peyer's patches

KEY TAKEAWAY- In small bowel obstruction the dilated bowel loops are in centre while in large bowel obstruction dilated loops are in periphery (haustra seen).

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2230

questions.text: A Twenty three year old female with two missed abortion usg suggestion of uterine anomaly which test will confirm diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Hysteroscopy + laparoscopy is Gold standard for diagnosing uterine anomalies.
  • Hysteroscopy assesses the endometrial cavity, while laparoscopy examines the external uterine contour.
  • Essential to differentiate septate (correctable) vs. bicornuate uterus.

Incorrect Options:

  • TVS (A): Good for screening but cannot reliably differentiate anomalies.
  • HSG (B): Detects anomalies but cannot distinguish septate vs. bicornuate uterus.
  • MRI (C): Accurate but expensive, not first-line.

questions.text: A 35 year old patient presented with severe abdominal pain and vomiting? His vitals are stable. What is the most effective way to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Gas under the diaphragm is a sign of perforation of the viscera. It is an emergency condition and would require patient stabilization with iv fluid and further exploratory laparotomy to find the cause of perforation and seal it.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 2080

questions.text: 10 year old child with normal bone mineral density. X-ray is given below Identify the diagnosis
questions.solution:
The given xray shows a radio-opaque line known as frenkel's line along with the history of bleeding gums in a child will help in diagnosing it as a case of scurvy. Since it has said Normal mineralization it cant be rickets. Radiographic features of scurvy

  • Generalized osteopenia
  • Cortical thinning: "pencil-point" cortex
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: expansion of the costochondral junctions
    • May relate to the fracturing of the zone of provisional calcification during normal respiration
    • Similar to the rachitic rosary appearance as seen in rickets
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring sign: circular, opaque radiologic shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frankel line: dense zone of provisional calcification
  • Trummerfeld zone: lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelkin spur: metaphyseal spurs that result in cupping of the metaphysis
  • Pelkin fracture: metaphyseal corner fracture

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2879

questions.text: A 9-year-old male was brought to emergency by the mother with difficulty in swallowing for the past few hours. He was noted to play unsupervised. Xray was taken. Identify the location of foreign body?
questions.solution:
Tracheal foreign bodies will orient in the sagittal plane (e.g. -coins will look like flat radiopaque circles on lateral films) while esophageal foreign bodies will orient in the coronal plane (e.g. -coins will look like flat radiopaque circles on AP films).

Reference: Guelfguat, M., Kaplinskiy, V., Reddy, S. H., & DiPoce, J. (2014). Clinical guidelines for imaging and reporting ingested foreign bodies. In American Journal of Roentgenology (Vol. 203, Issue 1, pp. 37-53). American Roentgen Ray Society. https://doi.org/10.2214/AJR.13.12185

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with chronic ear discharge and head ache with ear pain. CT revealed the following findings. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a peripherally enhancing collection within the temporal fossa. This is abscess. It is usually seen as a complication to chronic otitis media.

A cerebral abscess is a localized infection of the brain parenchyma. Most abscesses are caused by-hematogenous-spread from an extracranial location. Stages

  • Focal suppurative encephalitis (days 1-2)
  • Focal suppurative encephalitis with confluent central necrosis (days 2-7)
  • Early encapsulation (days 5-14)
  • Late encapsulation

On MRI, The necrotic core of encapsulated abscesses restricts strongly on DWI. Tl C+ sequences show a strongly enhancing rim.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 pg 353

questions.text: A patient met with road traffic accident bruising with left hypochondrium ecchymosis, his vital are stable ,Next best step is
questions.solution:
Abdominal trauma - first investigation efast

E fast shows Hemoperitoneum then:

if vitals stable - CECT

if Vitals unstable - exploratory laparotomy(to know the site of bleeding ).

choices.text: On usg streak ovaries and small uterus.
May be a risk of Mitral valve prolapse

questions.text: A mother bought her female child with short stature , low posterior hairline ,webbed neck,cubitus valgus lack of sexual development, compared to her classmates.on usg findings will be?
questions.solution:
The patient appears to have Turner's syndrome. Patients with Turner's syndrome have streak ovaries on USG as they do not develop properly and are seen as a linear streak of tissues.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1304

questions.text: Patient started on radio therapy for cancer. Least affected by radiation exposure.
questions.solution:
well differentiated tissue is least affected.

Neurons are affected the least with radiation among the given list of tissues.

Radiation exposure causes overall deterioration to the overall quantity and quality of bone by interfering with the trabecular architecture through increased osteoclast activity and decreased osteoblast activity.

Radiation causes abnormal apoptosis of intestinal stem cells, destroys the structure and function, decreases diversity of gut microbiota.

Radiation may destroy sperm cells and the stem cells that produce sperm.

Reference: Christenson's physics of diagnostic radiology page no 376

questions.text: Identify the muscle causing shown in arrow which also causes flexion of hip?
questions.solution:
The muscle shown medially is psoas major .Iliopsoas is a strong hip flexor.

Origin:

  • Transverse processes of T12-L5 vertebrae
  • Bodies and intervertebral discs of T12-L5 vertebrae

Insertion:

  • Lesser trochanter of the femur

KEY TAKEAWAY- It's important to note that the psoas major muscle combines with the iliacus muscle to form the iliopsoas muscle, which is the primary hip flexor.

questions.text: A cyclist met with RTA. He was apparently normal ,Doctor noticed bleeding on external urethral meters.What should be done next?
questions.solution:
In such cases the first thing is to rule out urethral injury.

First step RGU.

If rgu shows leak it means urethral injury is present . Don't put Foley in such cases.

Instead suprapubic catheterization is done.

KEY TAKEAWAY- IOC for urethral injury is RGU.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 211
